com.reactivecascade.functional

Class AbstractAltFuture<IN,OUT>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.reactivecascade.util.Origin
      • com.reactivecascade.functional.AbstractAltFuture<IN,OUT>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IAltFuture<IN,OUT>, IAsyncOrigin, ICancellable, IGettable<OUT>, ISafeGettable<OUT>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    RunnableAltFuture, SettableAltFuture

    public abstract class AbstractAltFuture<IN,OUT>
extends Origin
implements IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
    The common base class for default implementations such as SettableAltFuture and RunnableAltFuture. Most developers will not need to concern themselves with this abstract class.

    RunnableAltFuture overrides this class. TODO You may also use a SettableAltFuture to inject data where the from is determined from entirely outside of the current chain hierarchy. This is currently an experimental feature so be warned, your results and chain behaviour may vary. Additional testing is on the long list.

    You may prefer to use ImmutableValue that a similar need in some cases. That is a slightly faster, simpler implementation than SettableAltFuture.

    TODO Would it be helpful for debugging to store and pass forward a reference to the object which originally detected the problem? It might help with filtering what mOnFireAction you want to do mOnError

    • Field Detail

      • COMPLETE

        public static final ICancellable.State COMPLETE
        The state returned by a function which has no value, but is finished running.

        In some functional styles this is (somewhat confusingly) a "Null" object passed along the chain. We prefer to name each state explicity for debuggability and disambiguation.

    • Method Detail

      • cancel

        @CallSuper
public boolean cancel(@NonNull
                                 String reason)
        Description copied from interface: ICancellable
        A plain text reason must always be provided for debugOrigin purposes. This is carried forward through whay may be non-obvious asynchronous and active chain results.

        If the operation has already completed normally, this call may be ignored. A warning may be given to help clean up redundant cancellation.

        Specified by:
        cancel in interface ICancellable
        Parameters:
        reason - for easy debugging
        Returns:
        true if the action was cancelled, otherwise this call had not effect

      • cancel

        public boolean cancel(@NonNull
                      ICancellable.StateError stateError)
        Description copied from interface: ICancellable
        A reason, such as an error or manual calling of ICancellable.cancel(String), had trigger the transition to cancelled state upchain. This token is synchonrously passed downchain to inform all other chain step so that they clean up (alter external state such as closing resources or changing UI elements).

        The Reactive Cascade library exposes thread-safe atomic internal states for extension, default implementation replacement and transparency during debugging. Most application developers will not need to use this interface directly.

        Specified by:
        cancel in interface ICancellable

      • fork

        @NonNull
public IAltFuture<IN,OUT> fork()
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Place this IAltFuture in the ready-to-run-without-blocking queue of its IThreadType. If there is a IAltFuture.getUpchain() subscribe that will be forked instead until finding one where IAltFuture.isDone() is false.
        Specified by:
        fork in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:
        this, which is usually the IAltFuture which was actually forked. The fork may be indirect and only after other items complete because there is a search upchain (which may be a different branch spliced into the current chain) to find the first unforked from.

      • doFork

        protected abstract void doFork()

      • clearPreviousAltFuture

        protected final void clearPreviousAltFuture()
        Implementations of fork() must call this when completed. It reduces the window of time in which past intermediate calculation values in a active chain are held in memory. It is the equivalent of the (illegal) statement: setUpchain(IAltFuture) to null.

        This may not be done until isDone() == true, such as when the fork() has completed.

      • getUpchain

        @Nullable
public final IAltFuture<?,? extends IN> getUpchain()
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Find the previous step in the chain.

        Once IAltFuture.isDone(), this may return null even if there was a previous alt future at one point. This is done to allow a chain to reduce peak load and increase memory throughput by freeing memory of previous steps as it goes.

        Specified by:
        getUpchain in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:
        the previous IAltFuture in the chain, or null if this is currently the head of the chain

      • setUpchain

        public void setUpchain(@NonNull
                       IAltFuture<?,? extends IN> altFuture)
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        This is done for you when you add functions to a chain. You do not need to call it yourself.

        The implementation may call this multiple times to support merging chains. This happens most often when a method returns the tail of a section of chain. The returned from in this case is a new chain link stopping the merged chain section which might start burning before the merger is created to not burn past the merger point until the primary chain reaches that point also.

        Specified by:
        setUpchain in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        altFuture - the previous alt future in the chain to which this is attached

      • onError

        public void onError(@NonNull
                    ICancellable.StateError stateError)
             throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Notification from an up-chain IAltFuture that the stream is broken and will not complete normally. This RunnableAltFuture will be set to an error state.

        If an mOnError or catch method has been defined, it will be notified of the original cause of the failure. If the RunnableAltFuture's mOnError method consumes the error (returns true), subscribe anything else down-chain methods will be notified with #onCancelled(StateCancelled) instead.

        Specified by:
        onError in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        stateError - the state indicating the reason and origin of the exception
        Throws:
        Exception - if there is a problem performing synchronous downchain notifications

      • onCancelled

        public void onCancelled(@NonNull
                        ICancellable.StateCancelled stateCancelled)
                 throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Notification indicates an up-chain IAltFuture has been cancelled. This RunnableAltFuture will be set to a cancelled state and not be given a chance to complete normally. All down-chain AltFutures will similarly be notified that they were cancelled.
        Specified by:
        onCancelled in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        stateCancelled - the state indicating the reason and origin of cancellation
        Throws:
        Exception - if there is a problem performing synchronous downchain notifications

      • then

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
public <DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> then(@NonNull
                                                                                                              IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> altFuture)
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Start an action wrapped as an alt futre after this alt future completes. This next alt future may be on a different IThreadType thread pool.

        Multiple altFutures may be chained after the current alt future. They will be fork()ed in the orderin which they were attached. Depending on their thread type, the resulting execution may be concurrent or serial.

        Specified by:
        then in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Type Parameters:
        DOWNCHAIN_OUT - the type that the OUT value will be mapped to. This may not be a mapping alt future, in which case the type DOWNCHAIN_OUT = OUT and the value is also identical
        Parameters:
        altFuture - the next action in the chain
        Returns:
        altFuture

      • sleep

        @NonNull
public ISettableAltFuture<OUT> sleep(long sleepTime,
                                              @NonNull
                                              TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Pause execution of this chain for a fixed time interval. Other chains will be able to execute in the meanwhile- no threads are blocked.

        Note that the chain realizes immediately in the event of ICancellable.cancel(String) or a runtime error

        Specified by:
        sleep in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        sleepTime - to pause the chain, in timeUnit values
        timeUnit - to pause
        Returns:
        the input value from upchain

      • await

        @NonNull
public ISettableAltFuture<OUT> await(@NonNull
                                              IAltFuture<?,?>... altFutures)
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Continue chain execution once all upchain futures realize and have completed their side effects.

        The await operation will be cancelled or exception state and trigger IAltFuture.onError(IActionOne) if any of the joined operations have a problem running to completion.

        Specified by:
        await in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        altFutures - to pause this chain until they are done (IAltFuture.isDone())
        Returns:
        the upchain value of this chain, execution held until other alt futures complete
